Approximately 80% of acute hepatitis in adults is attributed to HEV. In Pakistan, epidemics of acute viral hepatitis were reported as early as the 1950s and 1960s. Many outbreaks of hepatitis E had been wrongly assumed to be caused by HAV. 42, 142 HEV has been found to be the main cause of acute-on-chronic liver failure in patients with underlying liver disease 143, 144 and acute liver failure in pregnant women, with maternal mortality ranges from 36–71%. The frequency of acute liver failure is higher (10–22%) in pregnant women with HEV infection than in men and non-pregnant women (1–2%).
145 HEV genotype 1 is prevalent in Pakistan, mainly transmitted via the faecal–oral route, 146, 147 consistent with the observation that 44·7% of samples from sewage water samples and fresh vegetables are contaminated with HEV.
148 The disease's subclinical course, the patient's expected self-recovery, and the high cost or unavailability of diagnostic tests for HAV and HEV mean that most cases are undiagnosed, leading to underestimated disease burden.
